Trashy and exploitative, Fifty Shades of Grey is a provocative piece of escapist fantasy.  In this dark and sadistic tale, a young woman named Anastasia Steele is drawn into a controlling and abusive relationship that's cloaked in eroticism.  Both the story and the characters are poorly written, and the performances by Dakota Johnson and Jamie Dornan aren't very good.  Also, the sex scenes don't feel congruent with the tone of the rest of the film; which undermines the development of the characters and their relationship.  And while there's an attempt to make Anastasia empowered, she's really isn't, and is emotionally and physically abused to break her of her puritanical views of sex and romance.  Fifty Shades of Grey is a vapid and pointless film that tries to get by on shock value.

A billionaire with an exclusive penthouse condo, private helicopter, private jet, over a half dozen expensive, luxury cars, CEO of his own company.  Very plausible.  A 27 year-old billionaire with all of this already in place, even though he was adopted at age four by a wealthy family. Not so plausible.   (Compare:  "In 1987 Gates was listed as a billionaire in Forbes magazine's 400 Richest People in America issue, just days before his 32nd birthday.")  Between the ages 15 through 21, Christopher Grey spent six years as a submissive to a married woman who was his dominant.  Then, consider that he had 15 submissives in the one particular "play room" we see in the movie.  The book says that the standard Submissive-Dominant contrasts were for three months and that he had four long term relationships in his life.  If you do the math, fifteen submissives, each lasting three months is 3.75 years (45 months).  Some of the submissives lasted more than three months.  We aren't told when he started his company or when his net worth hit one billion, but this information suggests that he had roughly six years, give or take, to accomplish this level of wealth.  I'm assuming that perhaps he went to college and either dropped out (like Bill Gates did) or he graduated at age 21.  How many Bill Gates are there in the United States?  Even if he did not attend college, it's not too plausible that Grey could be a billionaire.  Maybe the point was to make him unquestionably powerful, influential, extraordinary, and sexy to Anna.  
Anna's character is more conceivable.   She was a virgin at age 21 or 22, no prior boyfriends, graduating with honors (thesis notes) in English literature, with no definite plans upon graduation except for moving to Seattle with her friend and roommate.   (Just so happens that Mr. Grey resides in Seattle.)  She fell hard for Grey due to her vulnerability and because she was not attracted to any of her peers.  Enter the Knight in Shining Armor and she cannot resist him no matter what.   
There were so many telltale signs that she shouldn't get involved with a man who tells her point blank that he does not do romance; he only fucks---hard.  He warned her three times.  She is lucky that Grey did not destroy her when he reconciled the condition of her virginity.  In this respect, Grey is confusing as to what he is being that he could "make love" on this one occasion.  It could be that he decided that a woman with zero experience was an opportunity he shouldn't pass up.       
Aside from the fairytale of a 27 year-old billionaire, the problem with the movie is that it confuses the issue as to what Christian Grey really is.  If the information provided by Wikipedia is accurate, he seems to fall under one of the four classes of "sexual masochists", rather than one of the four classes of "sexual sadists".  Yet, Anna says to him "You're a sadist!" and he does not really respond or deny her labeling.  Is he in fact a sadist because of the type of punishment he administers such as whipping women with a belt and having them count each time they are struck?  Not until I saw that only people who must engage non-consensually could be a killer, rapist or a dominant that inflicts serious injury, was I convinced that Grey was not one of these people.   (And, there is doubt that "only" is accurate?)  I would have preferred that Anna's research on BDSM covered this ground because the movie producers and directors have a responsibility when dealing with sensitive topics with main stream audiences.   Secondly, wouldn't Anna's character who leads a very constrained life have this very concern that her life might be in actual danger?    
When Grey and Anna had a "business meeting" in a conference room, at his office, to negotiate the terms of the SD contract, it seemed that some viewers could easily confuse some of the practices that can be deemed non-BDSM with BDSM only behavior.   
How was Grey able to control his actions and how was he able to respect the limits set by his submissives?  He was sexually abused at age 15 having been seduced by an older woman to become her submissive, after all.  (Isn't that statutory rape?)  And, this is on top of abuse in the first four years of his life by his biological mother, a drug addict and prostitute.  Remember, he tells Anna that if he told her why he must punish women so severely, she would not have anything to do with him.  Part of the reason he had some self-control might be because he needed to win the trust of his female submissives, which he needed in order to maintain the consensual relationships.  The answer might also have to do with the doctor (probably a psychologist) that he confided in and the paid sex he utilized in his training to become a dominant, according to the book.   The movie should have touched on these aspects of Mr. Grey's behavior as the issue was left wide open.  Having formal written contracts does not imply an ability to have self-control and the capacity to respect for another's limits or preferences.  Without self-control the contract terms can be easily breached.      
The good thing about the movie was that the sex scenes, although I've read that they are covered in 20 minutes (roughly 18% of the movie), were kept minimal in number and filmed or edited to give the audience a brief view of the actual sexual activity so that our minds can fill in the rest.   The romance story was the emphasis, rather than, a full exhibition of soft porn.   
I'm not sure what the movie intended to say about BDSM.  Even if there was no intentional message, it does send out some harmful or distorted messages.

Anastasia Steele fills in for her sick friend interviewing the billionaire Christian Grey for their student newsletter. After the initial meeting and other brief encounters Christian finds her drunk and takes her home to take care of her while unwell, which is the beginning of their relationship. 

Based on the erotic fanfiction for Twilight, it is no surprise that the terrible story it was based on translates to an even worse story for this film. Comparable events that were stupid in Twilight become even more idiotic once the supernatural element is taken away. Most of the plot revolves around the signing of a contract for their sexual adventures to go forth but then it is later disregarded having no meaning. One of the main plot points has zero meaning. Story is only one of the many problems this movie has, with the prime thing being the script. If you are alive, then you would gag at how terrible everything anyone says is, just utter drivel. Actually to be fair it could have been spun as a comedy and then the script would be spot on. Onto the acting, which was not just bad - it was awful. Jamie Dornan could be a nice guy in real life, but as an actor in this film he was the worst; just the delivery of every line is unbelievable and as bland as sugar-free cheesecake. The constant lip biting which was focused on made it not sexy at all. Also a little thing, but why does she have a flip phone? Just why?

Moving on to what you really want to hear about, how well does the film portray the erotic moments of the book. As you may be aware, the infamous tampon scene was cut. What was left in was a few sex scenes similar to any other movie and then after 90 minutes of a 2 hour film they enter the playroom. Once inside, not much of what is shown would be even slightly steamy. Not helping the fact, is the utter lack of chemistry between the two leads. 

Not only does Fifty Shades Of Grey lack any deep exploration into the discovery of BDSM and its psychology, it fails as a simple movie that has a couple falling in love and having sex. The music adds more emotion then any character or plot point in the film. It fails as everything but perhaps a comedy. Half a point because it made me laugh.

This one was a bit different for me. It's going to definitely be a bit stranger to people that are locked up in their rooms or have been hiding under a rock, but Fifty Shades of Grey wasn't as shocking as I thought it would. Anastasia Steele (Dakota Johnson) is a college student that is filling in for a friend to interview businessman Christian Grey (Jamie Dornan). They meet and immediately Christian is drawn to Anastasia. Soon enough he starts popping up at Anastasia's work, grabs coffee and they both have a pretty sure thing attraction to each other. There's more to it though with Christian eventually revealing to Anastasia that he's into S&M. He wants Anastasia to sign a contract agreeing to all these things between them which he can and can't do. Anastasia seems to want it at first, but is really looking for more of a romantic relationship something that Christian has told her he doesn't do. The film continues on exploring their relationship and how controlling Christian ultimately becomes. I will say right off the bat Johnson and Dornan have a great on screen chemistry. They work off each other well (especially during the more intimate scenes) and they seem believable. Unfortunately, the films writing is atrocious. Dialogue seems off and wooden at times and unbelievable. The films pacing is also really bad. It's only a 2 hour film, but it almost feels like three. There's a lot of the movie that could have been cut down and edited for pacing purposes (especially the last half) where I felt scenes were just repeats of what had happened already. Overall, a different kind of film that women will more than likely enjoy more than men. It's a rent regardless to see if it sparks any kind of interest.

Oh jeez. You knew it was going to bad, right? The good news is it could have been worse! But ultimately Fifty Shades fails because the effort is tepid and unwilling to fully embrace its trashy origins. 

Fifty Shades of Gray and its sequels are mega-selling novels with worldwide success. Written by 50ish Brit E.L. James - the author made up this pseudonym to avoid judgment from her friends; a wise choice - Fifty Shades was conceived after she fell in love with the Twilight novels. James even desired to have Robert Pattinson play the role of Christian Gray! WTF.

 Most readers with discerning taste will tell you that those Fifty Shades books make the Twilight series read like Shakespeare. That is not a ringing endorsement of the material. So is the movie better? Certainly, but it still doesn't rise to the titillating levels of classic trash like Wild Things, 9  1/2 Weeks, and Showgirls. It's a little too self-conscious probably because a soft R-rating had to be required by any studio seeing dollar signs. I still expected more from a female director especially one who in her 40's bedded hot actor Aaron Taylor (Kick-Ass; Avengers 2) and had two kids with her boytoy. So Jamie Dornan (the enigmatic serial killer on Netflix's The Fall - everyone should be watching this) is a cool, emotionally vacuous Christian with just a hint of danger when he should exude a lot. And Dakota Johnson, daughter of Hollywood royalty Melanie Griffith and Don Johnson, is adequate as Anastasia Steele. But she's so whiny. He states clearly want he wants, even writes it in a contract! And she still bitches. It makes their torrid bedroom play - including flogging, bondage, and guilt - seem like a typical contentious relationship. He wants it his way and pays for it, but she still wants more. The things money can't buy - like love, respect, humanity. 

Two more of these are coming to theaters in the near future. My suggestion: recast Anastasia with someone more game than the amateurish Johnson and double down on the sex. It sells.

Pretty dull, considering the subject matter.  So this is about English major Anastasia Steele (Dakota Johnson).  She fills in for her friend to interview the mysterious billionaire Christian Grey (Jamie Dornan).  Her life is about to be turned upside down when he asks her out on a date, and she soon learns about his sordid bedroom activities.  It has been confirmed: this was originally conceived as Twilight fan-fiction.  Talk about setting your sights low; speaking as somebody who has seen all five Twilight movies, I can rightfully say: those are stories that don't need additional exploration.  It's a series that is already stretched as is, who needs to see the further adventures?  These are different characters, sure, but you wouldn't be able to tell from the female protagonists; both Bella Swan and Anastasia Steele are equals as far as being complete blank slates.  They're both not terrible looking, but they are not drop-dead gorgeous to the point that guys should be fighting for them; if either one of them were playing hard-to-get, I promise you: any guy would just move on.  This series is wildly popular, and I really haven't been able to determine why.  I have not read the books, but my wife confirmed that they are amateurishly written, overusing the word "clamor" more times than she could count.  What's frustrating about this material has very little to do with the depravity of it all, it is grating because the characters are so inconsistent.  As smart as Anastasia is supposed to be, she freaks out when Christian does his usual activities...  that is literally what she signed up for, and I do mean that a contract is drafted.  At the same time, Christian repeatedly says "I don't do romance", and then proceeds to take Anastasia on helicopter rides, plane rides, and out for family dinners.  Apart from having a dark streak in the bedroom, the guy does nothing BUT romance.  Both of them do nothing but send mixed signals, which would be frustrating in any relationship, never mind in a movie.  This is also really creepy, and again, it has very little to do with the kinky flair this story has to it.  Christian is essentially a sexually scarred Bruce Wayne throughout this, and he appears out of nowhere at Anastasia's place of work to surprise her with a date.  He also apparently has tracking hooked up to her BAL, because the moment Anastasia has one drink too many, he again, appears out of nowhere.  He has so many sociopathic tendencies that it would cause red flags to go up for anybody, but Anastasia remains oblivious throughout.  You can watch this as an unintentional comedy and have a movie to laugh at and make fun of all of the melodrama, much like The Boy Next Door, but that's really the best I can say about it.  This story will lead women to believe that you can change your man to be the guy of your dreams, which is not a message females today really need to be hearing.  Bottom line: both of these characters need to get over themselves, and I promise you will feel the same way if you choose to watch this.

The best thing about this film is that its quite clear Director Sam Taylor-Johnson has talent. Its clear she knows what she's doing, implores excellent cinematography and the music by Danny Elfman is riveting, as always. Whats sad, therefore, is how depressingly dull and bland this film feels. The reason why this may be is that the director had the mammoth task of adapting the utterly diabolical novel into a feature film, which wasn't helped by the author's constant need to intervene. What's worse, the director will not be continuing to the film's sequel, rather the author will become MORE involved as a screenwriter!!! 

The problem here is that the author's words are as eloquent and sophisticated as a child's dribble, something that doesn't transition well on screen. From the beginning, it's clear Taylor-Johnson tries to fight this, apparently cutting much of the author's ridiculous dialogue and numbingly repulsive torture sex and attempting to focus more on character development. Whilst I applaud this, truly, there are a couple of problems that arise as a result. The first, is that the film becomes exceedingly dull. Given 80% of the author's book is just, well, porn and with her limiting capabilities as a writer, most of the character development is either barely apparent or barely passable. This means that, for Johnson, she struggles to truly create a sensual film. The next is that, myself excluded, many will see this film for the same reason they read the books: it's an erotica story. But this film is not erotic, failing to live up to it's most 'useful' purpose.

Then we get to the central romance. Now, admittedly, both actors somewhat struggle with the screenplay given some of the grammatical inaccuracies get transitioned to film, making the foreplay much less interesting. Yes, this film does this. However, what truly sinks this film is the chemistry between the lead actors. Dakota Johnson is actually a very fine actress, and she really endevours to work with the terrible script and muddled story. Even in the first scene, her meeting with Mr. Grey, she excels in the script's comical (a nice touch by the director) elements and shines in the vulnerable moments. Unfortunately, Johnson is not matched well on screen. Jamie Dornan is wooden, uninteresting and frankly dull as a troubled Mr. Grey. He fails to become a truly engaging character and ruins the possibility of the film being even a guilty romance. 

Worse still, the film has a terribly unsatisfied, rushed conclusion that leaves many threads unresolved. This means that YOU have to wait another year just to see if they get together again, which they will as it's so damn predictable. But, I must firmly digress, nothing is achieved by having unresolved endings to a film where it doesn't add further intrigue to the ongoing story. Fifty Shades does not do this. It leaves you feeling cold and cheated. I would be more inclined to have viewed this film if I knew the author had no involvement and the romance was not as shitty.

This film achieved the impossible by making erotica boring. Like the Transformers franchise, its baffling how something so creative or steamy can become so bland and uninspired. Whats more ironic is how the film's title, Fifty Shades of Grey, epitomises how you'll feel after the credits roll.

"Fifty Shades of Grey"  was a decent depiction of the book. I felt like the actors were holding back on their performances, but the material of the book may have had something to do with this. What will Hollywood allow on screen? I didn't sense the passion between the two actors that I felt the characters had in the book. I wanted to feel this surrender on both sides that led to their bond. The movie does follow the book's timeline accurately. The story beings when Anastasia Steele covers for her roommate & best friend to do an interview of Christian Grey, who is a billionaire & Publishing giant. Anastasia & Christian immediately are attracted to each other during the interview. Christian decides to pursue her. As Christian shows up at her job unannounced & slowly reveals her is not quite the typical businessman. Anastasia becomes drawn to his dark sexuality. When Christian reveals his specific sexual tastes, Anastasia is intrigued & against her own red flags decides to take on this journey of exploration with Christian. When he shows her a contract he has her sign, and a room where she would be staying, the formalness of the arrangement sinks in. I think the movie should have less focus on the S&M relationship as it not considered a psychological illness, it is a choice between two consenting adults. What is interesting is the psychological journey of both characters. How they got to this place in their lives, and their need for completion.

No es novedad que un libro tan viral, con tantas ventas, al final del día realicen una pelicula sobre esta. Quiero decir que no leí el libro (ni lo leeré) pero en cuestión de adaptación y censura, supongo que tuvieron que cortar demasiadas escenas de sexo (algunas sumamente estúpidas) para que esta pelicula lograra por lo menos una clasificación "R" (o C en México) pero en fin, recuerdo que me senté frente a la computadora y me dije: "veré esta pelicula sin la necesidad de buscarle contras o con la intención de criticarla" pero esto no duro ni 10 minutos, la pelicula es un error total, en primer lugar, no me cabe en la cabeza la idea de que esta pelicula es romance y amor (el cual no lo es) pues yo solo veo una atmósfera tétrica, oscura, estúpida, repleta de Sadomasoquismo o masoquismo. ¿Desde cuando las mujeres ven a un hombre enfermo mental atractivo? no lo entiendo, ¿sera porque es millonario? ¿tiene autos de lujo? no tengo idea. Fifty Shades of Grey cuenta la historia de Anastasia, una estudiante virgen tímida que va a entrevistar a Christian Grey para un trabajo de su compañera de cuarto, la interacción de Jamie Dornan con Dakota Johnson es plana, no se sienten reales, Anastasia siempre tiene la misma cara: "orgasmo" "tristeza" "orgasmo" "enojo" "orgasmo".
La relación de estos dos es tonta, aburrida y poco interesante, ambos personajes no aportan nada de carisma, se vuelven tediosos y odiosos, por poner un ejemplo:
Christian Grey: "te regale un auto, una computadora, libros y todo lo que tu desees ¿seras mi sumisa? 
Anastasia: No, no quiero volver a verte (pasan 2 minutos) Te amo.
Por el amor de Dios, esta pelicula es basura! Con lo que respecta a las escenas de sexo, prometen mas de lo que son, así que no vayas con la idea de que veras escenas sexuales sumamente explicitas y polémicas. 
Sam Taylor-Johnson hace lo que puede en esta pelicula, no es culpa de ella que la pelicula no funcionara, de hecho se ve que puso todo su esfuerzo para que al menos fuera pasable, la culpa la tiene la historia (y por supuesto la escritora E.L James) una historia aburrida, nada interesante, mediocre y con poca originalidad (¿olvide mencionar que esto es "Crepúsculo" con sexo?) Lo unico perdonable de aquí es el Soundtrack (por parte de Danny Elfman) no es que sea una obra maestra, pero es lo unico decente que tiene esta pelicula (¿esto se le puede llamar pelicula? este termino no entra aquí...)

I must admit that I really wanted to see this movie after reading the book.  I was intrigued to see how the story would manifest itself on screen.  The book trilogy, of course, has had its critics.  However, you can't deny that it generated a worldwide frenzy and that it all started with the first book (which was also my favorite of the three):  "50 Shades of Grey."  To me, the first book had that intensity and magnetism that was required to get us to even pay attention.  Yes, things were dramatic and outlandish, but that's also what captivated us.  In turn, I was eager to see that play out on the big screen.  While I feel the movie succeeded  in some parts, I also feel it fell short in others. 

One strength of the movie were the compelling and accurate sets.  For example, Mr. Grey's office, his home, his closet, his playroom were all very well-done.   Christian Grey (played by Jamie Dornan) played broody and mysterious well.  Just like in the book, you were left wondering, curious, and unsatisfied with the lack of answers and openness from him.  Anastasia Steele (played by Dakota Johnson) played awkward well, but didn't seem to have the quiet confidence and strength of Anastasia I found from the book.  There were a few scenes where this was more true (such as in the boardroom meeting and at the very end), but because it was a bit lacking earlier it seemed a bit out of character when her quiet assuredness did show up.

However, given the sexual intensity of book, perhaps one of the bigger surprises and disappointments was that I did not feel the couple had the electric chemistry on screen that was required.  Some moments certainly worked; but other times it just seemed to fall a little flat.  Sometimes, I felt the movie moved a little too quickly on the subtle moments/gestures that could have increased the film's sexiness.  The film makers did this a couple times with Christian's drumming fingers or Ana's biting lip.  But sometimes I felt the sensuality quotient was compromised by a speeding by of certain details or even of dialogue.  I guess these moments could have been optimized to serve as foreplay, if you will, for the viewer.  

If you read and enjoyed the book, it's likely you will enjoy the movie.  But  I will admit I was hoping for more.  Let's hope what has been learned from this movie can help guide and improve the creation of the next two movies in the series.

So many horrible reviews.  The acting was excellent; all playing their roles perfectly. I think the reviews were poor because of societies perceptions (of love and sex) and expectations of what this film represents for us as individuals and for society.  For example, if someone is expecting a kinky porno, then they have obviously come to the wrong place!   

This movie has more to do with a deeply disturbed man with narcissistic tendencies, as he hides his pain through power and control.  In Christian's attempt and need to have power of Ana, he begins to lose himself along the way.  Like layers of an onion, he did not even realize he had, he starts to fear he is losing power over himself.  All the while, Ana is longing for the one thing that unites us all...love.  She starts to control him as a result of their mutual feelings, which is something he did not expect. The power of love cannot be controlled or contained in a simple contract or maintained with such strict rules.  This film represents a human's most basic need: LOVE.  It also shows us the long-term impact child abuse can have; shaping our personalities throughout a lifetime.   

Additionally, this film is controversial in many regards (Sadomasochism views are different from person to person, power/control roles, etc.) Also, many do not understand S&M culture.  It exists.  Power play is real.  While for most, this kind of sexual experience is new and possibly difficult to understand and grasp since this lifestyle is so controversial in real life.  

Some men and women may be offended by this film, taking this movie to represent abuse in relationships (which it DOES).  Although, difficult to view for many because of this, I believe cinema is an art form. I do not condone violence to anyone EVER.  I look at this film just as it is....a film.  It is just another way for us to broaden our horizons in understanding: ourselves, our perceptions and the way we view life.  So let's take a step back, and remember that as well.

Another Valentine's Day come and gone. (Also, St. Patty's went by in a blur.) I know I said I would post a review of this movie by Valentine's 2015 but things just got in the way. Maybe I just didn't want to be that guy who watches bad movies and bitches about it on the internets. But the experience draws in readers. Just so you know, I did watch Fifty Shades of Grey on Valentine's Day. And I probably should have consumed a glass of wine or beer beforehand, like fellow critic Christy Lemire had done (fyi: her review is the best).

To watch Fifty Shades of Grey is almost like a dare. Dare to watch a bad movie; or, dare to watch a movie about bondage and sadomasochism. The funny thing is that such sexual acts are looked down upon, and now we have a mainstream movie about the very act the majority condemn. What's even more funny is that I dare to defend this movie from all the naysayers, the ones who dismiss this movie because it opens the doors to the velvet underground.

This movie was incredibly tame and yet people were up in arms about the whole ordeal like they've never heard of such depravity. It's amazing that sex is still a touchy topic to this day, and I was equally as amazed when I pointed this out back in 2006 when I reviewed The Notorious Bettie Page. (see also my 2013 review of The To-Do List.) The bigger the budget, the higher the controversy. I guess everyone keeps overlooking the contract beween Mr. Grey and Ana and the two have to work out a mutual agreement before fucking. In short, it's all consensual. (But there is that one part that seems to rub people the wrong way, which I argue is almost the right response to illicit but some folk take it further by being offended).

But Fifty Shades of Grey isn't a landmark motion picture. It wants to be, as evident by its glossy presentation. Characters dressed sharp, walk in sterile environments, and have clean sex even if it's supposed to be unusual. Heck, even the trailer hyped this up to be way more than it should. I was sold even though I scoffed--it was also because of that horrible redux of Beyonce's otherwise brilliant "Crazy in Love." Nay, Fifty Shades of Grey is a punchline. It started off as a punchline (a Twilight fanfiction!) so there really is no reason to take it seriously. Dare to watch a bad movie? This is your ticket.

However, I am intrigued that a mainstream movie dares to make certain sexual acts mainstream. More often than not, the act itself is resorted to a punchline or underlying psychological disorder, or viewed in a seedy grindhouse where Travis Bickle and Betsy are on a first date getting schooled in sexual education. Just think, to watch Fifty Shades of Grey back in 1975 would've ended a relationship. Maybe your date would've thought you were crazy. You might've even gone to jail for watching such filth.

Though BDSM is also viewed as unnatural by our leading lady Ana or Anastasia (Dakota Johnson). She's essentially the good girl trying to tame the bad boy. It's like that one song that goes, "Why do good girls like bad boys?" She plays into Mr. Grey's sexual obsessions almost right away. She says he was intimidating but was drawn to him like she made it her personal mission to find out exactly what made him tick or why he is so enamored by her.

Ana is rather a blank character which I noted from the first five minutes. She's such a square, and I suspect many audiences are, particularly the ones who recoil to see Mr. Grey playfully spank Ana because she playfully bit her own lip (which is against one of his rules). Mr. Grey wasn't any better except looking good for the camera. He remains guarded which somewhat explains the character's shortcomings. A rather interesting scene is when he actually opens up to Ana, but he was only able to while she was asleep. The movie hints at his dark past but this entry doesn't explain it so we'll have to find out in the upcoming sequels.

For about two hours, they do more than just fuck. Mr. Grey indulges Ana in the fine escapades of the high life, so there are more ways these two oddly-paired consenting adults connect. It's painfully drawn out. It's sweet even if it's cheesy. I think the word that should be stressed is fantasy. Most fantasies don't take a whole lot of creativity, especially when it comes to sex. Show a little skin, play up the meek and dangerous personalities materialized by typically two attractive people. Maybe Fifty Shades of Grey is more of a modern fairy tale, but with fucking. You go "ooo" and "ahh" and "aww," and then maybe gasp a few times. 

I'm sure it was all intentional to make this dark, sexual world more appealing to the curious. It's weird, sure, but somewhat fascinating knowing that people keep leather, whips, and chains (oh my!) and other assortments to act out their fantasies. And finally, here's a movie that sheds light on a topic that was placed in the "special interests" sections at a video store or shown on late-night Cinemax. There was another movie about sex: Lars von Trier's two-part epic Nymphomaniac. It showed here in Albuquerque but only at the Guild and only at night. Fifty Shades of Grey played at chain theaters that had no qualm showing it during the day. Yet the sex is merely a conduit for the romance set to bloom. That was the other reason why this movie is fitted for mainstream.

Long story short: Fifty Shades of Grey was okay. Do what film critic Christy Lemire did. Have some wine, watch the movie with some friends, and giggle all the way through (seriously, read her review). It's really all you can do. Giggle like it's the first time looking through a nudie magazine. Because it is and it does feel like the first mainstream movie about sex since American Pie. Only less funny but more unintentionally funny. Win-win, I guess.

...but I dunno. One month later, no one's really talking about Fifty Shades of Grey. I made my "review" to make it seem like it's a landmark cultural event. But it's not. It's a punchline. Now everyone knows how the joke goes. Perhaps it overstayed its welcome. Like Bart Simpson's "I didn't do it" catchphrase. We need something new.

Boring, too talkative and lacking any direction, Fifty Shades of Grey is a disappointing adaptation of the female-targeting kin?? bestseller of E.L. James. Surrounded by all the hype coming from the books success, the movie fails to be anything more than a nicely calculated cash machine. Pretending to be bondage, kinky romance Fifty Shades of Grey is nothing but an impotent wanna-be-BDSM melodrama that utterly annoys.
Anastasia Steele (Dakota Johnson), a college graduate meets the young and ultra successful businessman Christian Grey (Jamie Dornan) during an interview she does for her best friend. An immediate spark flies between them and from that moment E.L. James' romantic melodrama starts. The beginning is intriguing and not bad at all, until nothing actually happens throughout the movie. Overlong dialogues and lame depiction of restrained passion, Sam Taylor-Jonshon's delivery is far from being even partially engaging. What totally ruins the movie is that the biggest asset of E.L. James' story, the BDSM and kinky elements are totally softened and replace by a boring soft-core scenes and completely artificial dialogues. 
It would definitely take some nerves to get through the final credits. With little to enjoy or to appreciate, Fifty Shades of Grey is a poor delivery that could have been a major improvement of its source material if it had been naughtier and kinkier.

If there is one thing Fifty Shades of Grey proves, it's that Hollywood has no interest in catering to the female gaze - even when making a film that is supposed to be a female erotic fantasy. Ignoring the issues that exist with the story and the misrepresentation of S&M practices, this is a film that refuses to accept what it is. All the sex scenes, which are devoid of anything resembling titillation, focus almost exclusively on the body of Dakota Johnson. Even with a female team behind the camera, the heterosexual male gaze cannot be quashed. When in comes of Jamie Dornan the film is down right prudish. We get to see almost nothing of his physique, with the camera quickly shying away from even a brief glimpse of his bare ass. No such reservations exist where Johnson is concerned. We get to see her naked in all her glory, being restrained and whipped, even if both are too tamed to shock or titillate. Fifty Shades of Grey shows a fundamental misunderstanding of heterosexual female desire, which is made more problematic with a target audience of straight women and on behind the camera. Maybe it's because everyone knows this is the epitome of trash and they are just collecting a paycheck. Dornan in particular looks like he's sucking on a lemon the whole film and is only there because the producers have some solid blackmail material on him. Dakota Johnson is the only one who manages to escape the energy sucking mess. She takes the mess in stride, realizing Fifty Shades for what it is, a chance to make a lot of money and get herself noticed. She delivers lines that make George Lucas look like a great writer of romance like she's in on the joke. She knows she's making trash and she's going to have fun with it. Johnson's efforts can't make Fifty Shades good. There is no power on Earth that can manage that feat, but she does make it bearable, even when she is reduced to writhing around restrained and naked.

NOTE: I NEVER READ THE BOOK AND THIS FILM DOES NOT ENCOURAGE  ME TO! Well, where to begin...Let's start with  this is nothing more than propaganda to demonize the BDSM community. You expect me to believe an English Literature major with a 4.0 had to google submissive? Caring for her new beau with broken foot kept her mom from flying, and "Ana" doesn't call her out on this? Then she meets this enigmatic billionaire, by the most cliched deus ex machina, who stalks his way into her heart, and then drives her away with his BDSM fetish. This wasn't written by some one with a clear understanding of the fetish world. If they did they'd have already seen Secretary and not filmed this garbage. I want to take a second to speak of the boggling use of color in this film. The color screaming the mood theme and emotion so loudly that i thought I was missing something. In Hero the use of color helps tell the story, but here it's hitting me over the head with things I already know because I pay attention to the story. On par with that is Christian Grey's wardrobe, between his mom, the fifteen other women, Ana herself, and all the boys at the gym and country club Grey would have a more diverse wardrobe. Not only that but he forces this drab sense of fashion on all his employees. His offices remind me of the world of Equilibrium, in which both feelings and artistic expression are outlawed and citizens take daily injections of drugs to suppress their emotions. The whole my last name is grey so that's my motif went out with 1980's Saturday morning cartoons. Had his last name been Cowslip or Steppenwolf...? 
The sex; how can you poorly edit a sex scene? It wasn't terrible. I had read the first couple pages of the book and found the writing to be insufferable, but I also fully expected the screenplay to iron out the kinks (heh) like with the "Twilight" movies, which had better material to work with in comparison. Anastasia is still a little unnecessarily inept and vapid at first and Dakota Johnson oversells her mousiness, but she proves herself a subtle comedienne in the hardware store and drunken voicemail scenes.

Jamie Dornan is sufficiently sexy and tortured and predatory, but the script is careful to make sure Ana's free will is at the forefront of every decision, though some may argue it's the illusion of freedom because she's so inexperienced and he's so persistent. Even so, that doesn't make her decisions any less her own, nor his lust any less an earnest desire for connection in the only depraved way he knows how. It's a problematic relationship dynamic, to be sure, and there's really only one Harlequin fantasy way to end it, but so far, the representation seems unmannered and unfettered (heh).

Curious? That's got to be the most apt publicity tagline for a me for a movie ever. It's not that I was curious about the content, per say. I was curious as to what the fuss was all about. Why are so many people so rabidly into this story? I had to know. No way on Earth would this ever be my kind of movie, but a phenomenon this big is hard for me to ignore. Plus, I had a coupon!

I don't need to explain the very thin plot to you, do I? No? Okay, moving on. I'll admit, there was a lot that fascinated and intrigued me about this film. It raised many questions about relationship roles as well as trust and expectations. A lot of it had me really thinking, in a way that stuck with me most of the rest of the day. Let me set things straight, I was pondering things, not fantasizing. Philosphically different. What part of their relationship was okay vs what should have been a red flag to send Anastasia running out the door. What would I be willing to put up with vs what's going too far?

Because for such a highly coveted romance, they really don't have a lot of substance there. Like any other movie relationship, the two inexplicably fall desperately in love immediately. They can't even bear to go a couple hours from each other. Gag. And for someone who claimed to be so devoted to his girl, Mr Grey really does put a lot of unfair and arguably abusive and manipulative pressure on her. Those are the sorts of things I was thinking about.

As far as the kink, it's my understanding that it's not a very accurate representation of the culture. I've been told that it should be based on trust, and that the open honesty and communication necessary to make it work make for a very solid relationship. That was not here whatsoever. Would I ever wanna read the book? Umm, no. Besides the fact that it's amateurishly written, I feel if I really wanted to know about such things, there'd be much better sources. Still though, I'd rather re-read LOTR.

I'm coming off pretty negative, there was some fun to it. Yes, Jamie Dornan was incredibly hot. And while Dakota Johnson is a little green as an actress, she did have a likability. It's my understanding that the screenplay smartened things up a bit, although much came off as very dumb. Without having read it, though, I could always tell when a line of dialogue must have been taken verbatum from the source. It was usually the really silly sounding lines that were meant to be sexy, often delivered in a fairly deadpan manner. Inappropriate giggles broke out in the audience. It was a fun fantasy to escape to, as long as you didn't pay too much attention to the details.

Would I see it again? Not any time soon. A couple days after I was at the movies with a friend. Our intended flick was cancelled due to a leaky roof in the auditorium. Her first suggestion "Would you see Fifty Shades?" "Again?! No" I resounded quite forcefully. We saw Imitation Game instead. Much better choice.

You know when you're watching a generic horror film, there's always a bunch of boring, talky scenes near the start where you're being introduced to the characters.. and nothing really happens? Imagine two really boring characters - one an impossible dullard of a girl who would probably fall for the "Nigerian Prince" email scam; the other an awkward, creepy, often-unintelligible, perpetually worried-looking man with an utterly laughable accent - and now imagine spending two brain-meltingly dull hours with them as they do essentially nothing, before the film randomly ends just when it seemed like it was about to go somewhere. That's Fifty Shades of Grey, an experience which is on every single level from top to bottom ill-conceived - it earns microscopic praise only for being fleetingly unintentionally funny. Oh, and surely it goes without saying that anyone who finds this gibberish to be "romantic" needs their fucking head examined...

I did enjoy Fifty Shades of Grey. There. I said it. I also enjoyed the books a lot merely because of how horrible the prose was. This is an enjoyably silly, schmaltzy love story to start the year off with that fans of the book will love but non-fans will HATE. The love scenes are pretty sexy and Dakota Johnson is TERRIFIC as Anastasia Steele. Jamie Dornan is a tad stiff, but that's only because the script has nothing for him to do but stand around and brood with his shirt off.

Then again, it's a VERY silly movie, so silly that I can't quite recommend you pay to see it in theaters. There's practically no plot. The entire movie is about Anastasia deciding if she should become Christian Grey's submissive or not. Every scene is him asking her "Have you made a decision yet?" and her responding "No, but soon..." Come on! Give us a better story! There's also the fact that the supporting actors, all very good (especially Eloise Mumford, as Anastasia's roommate), are COMPLETELY underwritten.

Let's just hope that Fifty Shades Darker (which does have a better plot) is a better movie.

I might have been previously too harsh on the Fifty Shades film when I reviewed it before. It's still definitely not anything exciting to watch... but compared to the book, it actually is better.

When making a film based on a terrible book series, you already don't have much to work with-- especially when the book's author constantly hounds, harasses, and pesters the director into giving her as much creative control as she can possibly have. If it weren't for E. L. James being a harpy on set, this film actually might have had even more intelligence associated with it. As it stands, it's already better than the novel (of course, a piece of shit cake is better than the novel), but think of how much better it would be if the terrible author of the book wasn't affiliated with its production?

There were, I admit, creative changes made in the script that never happen in the book that would have made the story poignant-- a word James doesn't understand, and never can understand.

I hated the Fifty Shades novel with every fiber of my being. It's romanticized abuse and the protagonist is highly unlikable. In the film, however, she has a personality that her blank slate counterpart in the book doesn't. She has a bit more fire, and a bit more strength. Not too much, but more. It's like the producers of the film KNEW that the book was terrible, and wanted to turn it into something beautiful. That's never easy to do, and I have to admit that I feel sympathy for them when having to deal with the book's author hounding them the entire time, picking apart every little thing and demanding things "be added" or "be removed" or changed.

I'm less fascinated with the film itself than I am with what the film COULD HAVE BEEN without E. L. James' influence. She needs to realize that there just are more creative people than her, and to allow some breathing room. Her books are boring-- PAINFULLY boring. But the movies have a chance to turn that possibility of saucy narc-and-supply relationship into something engaging, enthralling, and fun.

I know that James will remain glued to people on the next film as well. I can only pray that they don't allow her to dog them around in the same manner Christian proudly does in her awful books.

FIFTY SHADES OF GREY review by Mike Smith 

Literature student Anastasia Steele's life changes forever when she meets handsome, yet tormented, billionaire Christian Grey. 

When I write a review I try to find at least one good thing about every movie. That being said, Fifty shades of grey had NOTHING to contribute to my cinematic love. The cast is terrible; Dakota Johnson and Jamie Dornan have no on screen chemistry. They don't keep us interested in the film because they can't act. At one point Charlie Hunnam was attached to play the main role of Christian Gray and after wasting a hour and fifty minutes on this abortion I really think he would have brought some acting to this train wreck. The writing is crap and Christian Gray came off more like a stalker and a creeper. Anastasia Steele seems like she is slow and dumb. One thing that pisses me off about this movie is that if Christian Gray was just an average guy, not a billionaire, the tone of the movie would be completely different. The music is just dark ominous tones or crappy covers of songs.  

And let's not forget the sex scenes, there is nothing special about any of it. So what, you see her boobs not a big deal, but the sex parts (which is what the books are built upon) are nothing to be excited about. I should have just watched a real porno! There would have been a better story and much better acting. It makes me cringe knowing there are two more movies coming soon. Cheers and remember I watch the crappy movies so you don't have too.

That advice turned out to be very good advice and I had to focus on suspending my disbelief to get down under the terrible writing and get to the meat of the story, as it were. I enjoyed this movie because of it's unconventional story! There are not a lot of movies out there strictly for adults these days. The PG 13 rating has been given to a big portion of the industry to bring in the "tween" audiences and their money. I was not convinced that Jamie Dornan was right for playing the part of Grey but it turned out that he did a good job. The chemistry could have been better between the two leading actors, but I got the idea she was somewhat reluctant to get involved with the guy in the first place. Most will never experience that type of relationship, however I saw a sensible depiction of what it might be like if I were. It was a fresh diversion from the typical Nicolas Sparks algorithm that's been playing on repeat for the past decade and yes, it did leave me wanting more.

Twilight's characters were so shallow that there was absolutely nothing interesting about any of them. The injection of sex into these characters only made them just a little more interesting, but all it really did was change an emotionally-pornographic story into a sensually-pornographic one. As a matter of fact, the sex scenes in the movie are the best part to watch, because at least there was a sense of discovery on the party of Anastasia that the audience could get to experience. Everything else in this movie (and story) is so banal that no amount of acting presence (which isn't much) can save it.

While the film has its moments of unintentional hilarity, impressive cinematography, an enjoyable Danny Elfman score, and the performances by the leads are decent, But with its poor writing, plot, and characters, Fifty Shades of Grey is ultimately a dull, uninteresting, and unsatisfying bore!

Sam Taylor-Johnson's film of E.L. James's Twilight fan fiction-turned-phenomenon is dreadful to be laughable nor so brilliant to be powerful.
Instead, they get a sparky first third, a rote obsessive love story, anodyne kinkiness, contentious sexual politics, slivers of skillful filmmaking and a promising turn from Dakota Johnson (daughter of actress Melanie Griffiths and actor Don Johnson).
The set-up is a simple one: bookish Anastasia steele (Johnson) meets Christian Grey (Jamie Dornan), a business tycoon hiding a troubled past, a lust for BDSM and a penchant for playing really miserable tunes on the piano. He lavishes his wealth on her hoping she'll sign a contract to become his "submissive". She yearns for a more typical movie-and-a-dinner-type relationship but tests her 'hard' and 'soft' limits anyway.
As the emotions get more intense and we begin to learn the motivations underpinning Grey's need for dominance, the film gets bogged down in repetitive, earnest romantic drama.
Dornan as Grey is no hero, and Johnson was so understated it was like she wasn't even there at all. she gives Anastasia both a strength and sense of humour.

Why? Just WHY? There is very little this movie does right. Even the supposed "sexual content" is so underwhelming that I was playing Sudoku on my tablet and having more fun from it than anything shown in the movie.

So, the film version of E.L. James' Fifty Shades of Grey sucks hard. Are you shocked? I actually was. Shocked that Fifty Shades of Grey on film is a such a dull, bloodless affair that's about as erotic as prego porn. Sure, the book sucked too, but the book had real heat to it. You knew you weren't reading literary excellence. James too had the common sense to suggest that there are actually real motives behind dominants and submissives.

What we do have onscreen, from slumming director Sam Taylor-Johnson (Nowhere Boy). from a super sanitized script from Kelly Marcel, is the story of poor virginal English major Anastasia Steel (Dakota Johnson). She finds the perfect man in 27-year-old tech billionaire Christian Grey (Jamie Dornan). Christian's only flaw--he gets off on blindfolding Ana, tying her up in his Red Room of Pain and cuffing and flogging her. Got that?

The movie presents a solution to the question of 'What's a girl to do?' and apparently the answer is do everything she can to domesticate the guy so he'll charm her parents and they'll live happily ever after. So who's being dominant now? Rather than dinner and a movie, Christian offers a contract that spells out everything, from  how he wants to hold Ana in bondage with sex toys like butt plugs and genital clamps, but, this being a consensual love story, Ana refuses anal and fisting. It's a hell of a negotiation. Christian makes things sweeter by dressing Ana in high fashion, getting her a computer (hello product placement), and supplying her a sports car, taking her to the Pacific Northwest in his chopper where they go hang-gliding and buying her first editions of Thomas Hardy novels. The rough stuff? Hardly there.

Since the film is essentially trying to be an adult version of Twilight, that can still appeal to the young ones, the rough sex is few and far between. Director Taylor-Johnson shoots all the crotch touching and nipple nuzzling like a strict school marm making sure not to let the kids have too much fun. The wicked soundtrack, from the likes of Beyonce, Sia and Ellie Goulding, make the sex scenes look more like old music videos. There's no grit, just gloss. The movie shies away from real dirty details like bodily fluids and bruises save for a quick peek at Christian's junk as he spanks Ana.

Fifty Shades of Grey is porn for tweens, and a piss poor substitute for the book's darker, bloodier instincts. The tampon scene is missing. Too bad, it could have given the movie something it desperately needs: real sparks and heat. Johnson (The Social Network, 21 Jump Street), daughter of Melanie Griffith and Don Johnson (no relation to the director either), plays all of this swill for real. She's the film's one bright spot in a film that removes the joy of sex worse than the movie Shame (at least that was intentional). Johnson thankfully too gives Ana much-needed intelligence the book never hinted at. Dornan, sadly, is practically zombified. The Irish model-turned-actor (he's amazing as a serial killer on the BBC series The Fall) seems to be too frightened or embarrassed or both to really give anything to the role. This Christian has no shades. He's merely a human doll with nary a hint of the darkside and what drives him. The better to not scare away the girls.

Critics who gave the film favorable reviews seemed grateful it wasn't as dirty and shocking as they thought it'd be. I'm way disappointed. Fifty Shades of Grey is horribly sanitized. It's most punishing feature is the crushing boredom it inspires.

Here's what I think... This movie is a female fantasy and it is all from the woman's point of view. Therefore, the female character makes sense, but the male character is all over the place; his actions and motivations don't make any sense except as a foil for her. The title suggests that the writer might even be somewhat aware of what she's doing -- a character with "50 shades" should be one with so many variations that he is inscrutable. Unfortunately, rather than being multifaceted and mysterious, Mr. Grey comes off as a muddle of conflicting cliches. 
If the story could be taken seriously at all, perhaps it is as a study of the contemporary woman's fantasy of the ideal man. According to this movie, he is rich, good looking, young, driven, persistent, superficially dangerous but soft on the inside, uber-successful but not too bright, and totally malleable to a woman who knows what she wants and is willing to stand up for herself.
There really should be a scene at the end where she wakes up and realizes that she has fallen off a ladder at the hardware store and bumped her head.

This is a wonderful movie for anyone studying psychology. Admittedly I had no interest in reading the book or joining in on the hype surrounding it. It is my opinion that this movie truly explores the character of Mr. Grey and not his counterpart Ana. Although Ana's life is more fully explored in the movie and her character is the one audiences are lead to be able to relate with, I do not believe she is as important as Mr. Grey. 
A boy neglected by a drug addicted mother, adopted by a wealthy family that also neglects him, sexually abused by a family friend, and ultimately the circle of abuse continues as he himself becomes the abuser. This is a story about a man that begins to overcome the emotional obstacles that his past has caused and the woman he idolizes for her innocence. 
True love is the ability to accept someone regardless of their flaws. I have been in many relationships in which I have made compromises for the one I loved. I am in no way condoning abuse, there is a distinction between abuse and sadism which Ana was unable to comprehend. 
Ultimately to truly understand this movie you must look beyond the surface, as is true with everything in life.

This film had a lot riding on its success and while it was a financially successful film, the film itself is a bit of a mixed bag. First of all you need to know that it seemed that everyone tried their best to make the best film they possibly could. From the great performance from lead Dakota Johnson to the great directing by Sam Taylor Johnson and even the amazing soundtrack, the film was firing on all cylinders...until it came across the screenplay. The majority of the dialogue in this movie is so laughably bad, it makes the film border on a guilty pleasure or semi comedy. Granted with the material the filmmakers had to go on they did their best. Actor Jamie Dornan didn't seem to comfortable with his lines which made his performance seem fairly wooden and dull, that also contributed to the fact that the leads share a minimal amount of chemistry. All in all the film missed the opportunity to make a serious drama and instead landed on a sillier version of "9 1/2 Weeks". If you go into this film with minimal expectations and don't take it seriously, you might be pleased. C

Fifty Shades of Grey is that rare experience that leaves you angry, as it has insulted my intelligence and my attention.  I don't even know where to begin.  The cast try their hardest to make it past a worthless script and laughibly awful dialogue.  Its involves Anastatia Steele, a young woman who interviews billionare Christian Grey.  The two become quickly attracted to each other and she is pulled into his lavish world, but she soon discovers he has a dark secret.  Dakota Johnson plays Anastatia and Jamie Dornan plays Christian.  These two have little to no chemsitry on screen, with Johnson feeling like a young child against Dornans creepy and completely serious performance.  A little humor could have done the characters some good, since the complete lack of any fun between them made their romance as boring as it comes.  This is a film that was made strictly because of the success of the book, which most would agree is porn for soccer moms.  It was not a well recieved book so I never imagined the film would be any better, but I gave it the benefit of the doubt nonetheless.  But this erotic Twilight ripoff simply doesn't do anything interesting for nearly two hours and gives us a joyless and strange romance with actors with absolutely no chemistry.  To call this film an expensive porno would be accurate, as the story here is about as intersting as a porno.  Fifty Shades of Grey will certainly become a series, but it will clearly be made out of greed and not quality.

Fifty Shades of I can't believe I watched this twice. I read the trilogy - not because I'm into the romance genre (I'm a love of the classics, and yes I've actually read "Tess of the D'Urbervilles") but because a ridiculous number of my married and single lady friends read them and well, curiosity got the better of me. We all know how terribly E.L. James writes and the subject matter leaves a lot to be desired plus we've pretty much heard enough criticism about the unrealistic nature of the Christian-Anastasia BDSM relationship. We don't need to rehash the domestic violence discussions. 

Let's talk about some of the merits of the movie:

So, we have one young woman about to graduate from college who finds herself reluctantly interviewing the world's most eligible bachelor under thirty. He's smitten almost immediately and she's intrigued but intimidated. The deadly hot billionaire decides to engage in what could easily be defined as moderately stalkerish behavior meant to entice the young woman into a dominant/submissive relationship. Guy engages in some fairly elaborate stunts to get girl's attention including showering her with gifts even though he claims adamantly that he's not the "hearts and flowers kind of guy." No, instead he sends first editions of Thomas Hardy novels, a new Apple laptop, and an Audi coupe. We should all be so lucky. And though this guy wants to be in control, dominating every part of the girl's life, it becomes very clear by the end that this isn't the case at all. She finally decides she can't take the Red Room, his need to punish her or his inability to give her "more," so she bolts and leaves him completely bewildered.

Let's talk Anastasia and Christian from a young adult perspective. It's hard to give yourself completely to someone else when you're not entirely sure who you are and have little life experience to rely upon. Christian has not exactly had the most traditional of upbringings. In the first novel/movie, we know he was adopted by the very wealthy and successful Greys, that his biological mother was probably on Child Protective Services frequent flier, and that he lost his virginity to one of his mother's friends at the age of fifteen. He's lived a full life at the age of 27 and is hesitant to let anyone really know him or touch him. Anastasia is completely different. She meets Christian and he believes (somewhat mistakenly) that she would be the perfect submissive based on his first impression. Ana is anything but submissive. 

It's a welcome change in the screen adaptation. Typically screen adaptations pale in comparison to their literary counterparts (with a few notable exceptions). This is the first time I've read a book and been more pleased with the movie. Kelly Marcel omits a lot of Ana's tiresome inner monologue and indecisiveness in favor of a slightly more assertive and concerned female character. Unlike the book, Ana asks a lot of Christian and finds a way to pull him out of his comfort zone and into hers. For a person who professes to exude control in all matters, Christian loses himself fairly quickly in his pursuit of Ana. What we end up seeing is a power struggle between two truly dominant people looking for the right opportunity to submit to someone. Christian speaks often of trust and comfort in submission. He ultimately has to trust her as much as she has to trust him in order for their relationship to continue. 

The biggest point of controversy is Christian's treatment of Anastasia. He is constantly aware of her location, inserts himself into her life in overbearing and creepy ways, and tries to direct her life. Fortunately for everyone, Anastasia is relatively astute and keeps a sense of humor and propriety about the situation often poking fun at Christian for his behavior. There are points where being sexually adventurous borders on overtly sadistic actions that make us uncomfortable particularly towards the end. Ana questions this too even going as far as to ask "Why do you want to punish me?" She asks in a way that most of us vanilla types are asking, too. What is it that drives people to BDSM? Where Christian is concerned, we don't get the answers until later in the trilogy. But we're also wondering why exactly he is so obsessed with Ana. Is it love? When she admits her feelings for him, Christian acts completely astonished that anyone could be in love with him given his sexual perversions and generally screwed up mental state. Honestly, being in love in your early twenties is a lot like that - two complete head cases coming together to make some sort of sense in the world. Honestly, who are we really to judge? There's something to be said for romanticizing these kinds of relationships that border on abuse, but you really could cite how frequently they exist in films and literature - Tess of the D'Urbervilles is a fantastic example. Besides the erotic "mommy porn" reputation the novel and film have garnered, maybe people actually relate in some way to the material. It's not just escapism but something else. 

Other points: There was a startling lack of development of the other central characters from the novel. In a trilogy, you have a little more time to waste I suppose. The chemistry between Jamie Dornan and Dakota Johnson is initially shaky but works itself out a bit by the end. Sam Taylor-Johnson actually did a really fantastic job of directing a film that arguably had a lot of high expectations from the outset. it's unfortunate she won't be around for the sequels. The sex scenes were, in my opinion, relatively tasteful and not exploitative. I saw more of Dakota Johnson than I needed to although Jamie Dornan did look fantastic in those infamous distressed jeans. Oy. 

Bottom line: I saw it with girlfriends in the theater the first time and watched in on Blu-ray alone the second time. I was entertained. And sometimes, that's what's really important.

I saw this film last month and to be honest, i actually liked it. I mean first and foremost you have to know that the book itself isn't really good so you shouldn't really expect a lot from the film.

 I've read the book and comparing it to its film adaption, I can say that the film's way better. They made it LESS about the sex and MORE about the "romantic" love story of Grey and Steele. Also, they gave Steele's character some humor which for me was such an important element. 

In terms of technicalities, the film wasn't "over-the-edge" it's okay. Nothing special. 

In terms of soundtrack, the film has superb songs! It' actually sets up the mood quite well. I cried a bit when Ellie Goulding's "Love Me Like You Do" started playing. Weird right?

In terms of acting, Dakota did an okay job. She started a bit off (her character was supposed to be awkward-cute, but she made her seem awkward in a bad way). Jamie's portrayal of Grey on the other hand was less than okay. He pulled of the sexy and "let's fuck" part but the INTIMIDATING part not quite well. The way he talked also distracted me i don't know why.

All in all, I think the film's still worth watching and is not as bad as to what people/haters are saying. I'm actually giving it a 6-7 over 10 grade.

Maybe it's because expectations were so low, maybe it's because it was released at the same time as Jupiter Ascending, but (dons body armour, cuts lights) this isn't nearly as terrible as its reputation would suggest.  

On the surface it's actually kind of... adequate.  Sam Taylor-Wood's direction is, for the most part, network TV drama standard, but it's really what's needed for a tale like this.  She does kind of choke towards the end, not yet up to the task of using the codes of cinema to show progression in the third important scene set in the same room with the same characters, but she's also smart enough to bring some intentional laughs to the early scenes that undercut the general unlikelihood of the set-up.  Jamie Dornan blunders his way through role that he's somewhat miscast is, whereas Dakota Johnson defies expectations and carries herself reasonably well.  The script starts totting up the logical inconsistencies in scene one and doesn't let up (a college newspaper scores an interview with a billionaire industrialist and lets the assigned journalist chuck a sickie and send her flatmate? How small is their journalism programme?) but it's not so much offensive as lazy.  And assumes the audience is lazy.  And is probably right.

For all the furore and hand-wringing over the film's supposed misogyny, there's really not a lot to support it.  This is the story of a naïve young woman who flirts with the possibility of an unfulfilling and one-sided relationship (spoiler) before growing to a point where she not only walks out but gains the upper hand.  If this were a thriller instead of a romantic drama and she cut his balls off instead of walking out, it'd be hailed as a trashy feminist triumph.  Yes, the film exaggerates Anastasia's stupidity in the early scenes, not because it is misogynist but because it is a Hollywood film and it's drawn in broad strokes - the women in Pygmalion stories are styled to be unrealistically dowdy and Anastasia is styled to be unrealistically dumb because it gives her room to grow.  Outside the central pairing, virtually every character in this film who says or does anything is female - it passes the Bechdel test with flying colours (insert your own 'grey' joke).  Possibly the closest it comes to real woman-hating behaviour is in casting Academy Award winner Marcia Gay Harden as 'the mum'.  If you honestly think this film deserves to be singled out for its treatment of women, you've had the pleasure of missing an awful lot of Hollywood's output for the past couple of decades.

The film's portrayal of BDSM and the people who practise it is kind of rubbish, it's poorly researched and it relies heavily on the naivety of the mainstream audience.  That said, any offensiveness relies heavily on the fact that in portraying a subject rarely touched on by mainstream film, or even in indie film that follows a traditional narrative, there's certain to be an extent to which it is taken to be 'the' story of whips & chains romance rather than 'a' story.  Yes, the film centres on a character whose interest in BDSM is suggested to be closely aligned to negative stereotypes of alternative sexuality; past abuse and emotional unavailability.  But these intimations come principally from other characters - who share the same preconceptions and prejudices as folk in the real world.  To criticise the film for taking a negative stance on BDSM is to criticise the characters for their inability to accurately pathologise themselves.  If anything, it meets the kink community halfway by its declamation that dominance is no excuse for abusiveness and shan't be taken as such.

Is it any good?  No, not really, but benignly rather than offensively so.  There's no point rushing out to see it because there's nothing to get excited about, but if you saw either of the leads on the poster and thought "I could stand to watch something that features that person's arse prominently" and it's offered on your streaming service of choice half price one day and you've got an enormous pile of ironing or something to do, then you could actually do worse.

I guess it's always hard to make a good film from a highly popular book. Particularly when the book in question's main selling point was making curiosity about sado-masochistic sexual relationships trendy and mainstream ( " I can read a book and talk about S-M stuff and not feel a weirdo!" ) .
 Plus the fact that the movie failed in its prime objective- to get some real chemistry between the lead actor and actress.. Well, actually, I suspect that  the prime reason for making the movie was to make money, and it  kinda showed.
The male lead had a hard job - he was supposed to be a Dominant, but actually showed classic submissive behaviour throughout the film - it would appear that the film-makers were a little sketchy on the nature of S-M/  top-bottom relationships.  I can't imagine ( although I clearly don't speak for) women were much attracted to Mr Grey, however much they might have wanted to be. Anastasia(!)  Steel  also showed a rather transparent lack of pull towards Mr Grey- her best moments were when he took her for a spin in his glider. ...
So a poor to average date-movie where the chap is attractive because he's rich.....I think it's been done a thousand times before, and often better.

Mind, I was VERY jealous of the "red-room" and all the beautiful equipment in it.   ;)    And MIss Steele did have a nice bottom.

Excelente cinta. Independientemente de todo el morbo que se generó por las redes, de toda esa crítica, a mi gusto, mal fundamentada (especialmente de personas que aún no han leído el libro pero que se sienten expertos en el tema como el resto de todólogos de internet), y aunque esté en contra de muchas opiniones, se me hizo una buena película, con algunos cabeceos, pero por demás bastante interesante cómo adoptaron el tema. La disfruté mucho, pero, contrario a otras películas basadas en cómics donde yo tengo que dar explicaciones, ahora me tocó ser a mi el instruido y que me fueran explicando de la mano cada una de las cosas que no muestran en la película o que bien, por la falta de tiempo, no alcanzan a explicar, y es que, como me comentaron, es bastante difícil adaptar una obra así de completa en tan poco tiempo (algo muy común con las adaptaciones literarias... con ligeras excepciones en donde sí las han extendido como el caso de las dos últimas de Harry Potter, las dos últimas de Amanecer y las 3 últimas de El hobbit). Sin embargo el tabú que crean este tipo de temas o la parodia de la que son objeto y demás críticas se desbaratan cuando te sientas muy a gusto, con la persona que amas, a ver una película de esta categoría donde el erotismo, pero más allá de las imágenes fuertes, de esa filia que es el "bondage". Resulta un buen manjar al gusto de conocer comportamientos y de verlos dramatizados de una forma tan cuidadosa y con un excelente soundtrack. Definitivamente no es una cinta para verse en pareja y mucho menos una película que necesite toda la ridiculez y faramalla de disfrazarse para verla como parodiaban en las redes. No, esta es una cinta para ir a verse en serio y disfrutarse ampliamente.

Sam Taylor-Johnson's character driven erotic romance drama thriller falls flat just ten minutes into the movie. The picture has a lot of issues. When one is dealing with a drama involving characters or in other words a character driven picture the emphasis all the way should go to how the characters are written , shown and performed.The first major problem which marred the whole narrative was the ludicrously boring and badly written screenplay by the four writers. Not only are the characters poorly written but also poorly developed throughout the length and breadth of the film and as a consequence it does drags and takes the venom of the plot revolving around the characters.A film which possess erotic romantic scenes must and should be well shown and there is where the direction falls apart. None of the romantic scenes throughout the picture have any sense of purpose or moments or even evocative imagery in either direction. Even thought the scenes are well lit and the plot basically rests on the imagery of the scenes , they just fall flat and redundant as the contract written. Sam Johnson also fails to bring out something special of a terrible screenplay and also the actors. Now the actors themselves are not bad in portraying what they are told to portray even though they are no way near the potential. The lead characters are such one dimensional in nature that nothing interesting can be pulled out of the hat . So the plot was ultimately and constantly reminded to us in form of SMS texts and email replies . Those were probably the only understanding of the nature of the leads. So the whole process of collaboration from the script to the director to the actor stumbled within the first couple of minutes and hence the result is a pretty much the synopsis of the picture. From a cinematography point of view , I wouldn't say it was bad. On the contrary from a technical side I thought the setting was nicely lit and atmospheric bringing some tension to the otherwise dull storytelling. There were also nice use of colors. Seamus McGarvey can hold his head high. Another tool that could have been nicely used was the score which again lacked any sort of purpose in enhancing the picture. It was thrown into it to make it sound nice. There is no artistry shown by the director in any department which could have enhanced the characters a little bit more than what was written. Having said all these and well most of them are negative I would like to say the premise of the source material was probably not the best and certainly the casting was too much for non exceptional actors to handle. So a potentially bad premise turned into a preposterous screenplay probably shouldn't have made the theaters at all and could have gone straight to video.

BDSM was merely the tool, the intent is clear. Grey gets off on abuse because he is "fifty shades of f*cked up". He was abused as a child and never knew his mother. Abuse is all he knows and is as close as he can get to a relationship. If you critique the film for not living up to the Sex of the book, I think you've lost the message that was intended by the director. Ana's "No" echoes every abuse, in particular every rape, around the world. It was the cry all victims either fail to voice or goes ignored.

So, overall i think the movie is only good at making bunch of dollar for the studio but not able to give audience the romance, the intimacy, and I really hope that the sequel to this movie will satisfy our expectation for the whole trilogy which is basically romance, but with a twist.

Despite lead actress Dakota Johnson's best efforts to salvage the material (which are certainly appreciated) and some moments of trashy entertainment, Fifty Shades of Grey is a bad movie, plain and simple. The script, while better written than the book (not like that's hard, but still), is still blunt, obvious and filled with groan-worthy dialogue. The talented Johnson is saddled with the wooden and stiff (and I don't just mean down there) Jamie Dornan as her co-star, leaving her to desperately grasp for any semblance of screen chemistry the movie may periodically flirt with. The direction is handsome yet lacking much real style or personality, the plot keeps repetitively dragging along in circles like a BDSM-curious dog chasing its own tail, and the titular sex scenes are underwhelming and tame, trying too hard to class up and make Hollywood-friendly what should be trashy and shameless. Top that off with one of the most frustrating and anticlimactic movie endings in recent memory and I'm left feeling uncertain as to how anyone could be satisfied enough to hunger for the inevitable sequels.

Oh who cares about the synopsis. I'm sure it has been done to death by now. Gosh I was so ashamed about watching this film and for the first hour (I confessed so to my husband), I was kind of ashamed about liking this film. Well not like; more not hate.
