It is inconceivably bollocks about the BDMS scene; considering the BDSM theme it is remarkably vanilla; being a film about female sexuality there is a lot more tits and fanny than there is male nudity. I mean not one full frontal? really queen? However I believe the major fault in this film is Jamie Dornan. In all his press junkits he came across as quite clueless and WOW does he not sell the Dominant here. Zero chemistry with Dakota Johnson and just doesn't really look suited (scuse the pun) to the part. I think Christian Grey needs a more Hugh Jackman stature about him. Not read the books, but it would seem that he needed to be more of a presence.

Anyway, I did enjoy Dakota Johnson a lot. She completely sold her character and was a joy to behold. It is shot really beautifully. Nice, not to obvious grey wash to everything. 
Fortunately for me the film takes a nose dive into the dung heap in the last half. The "do your worst" is ridiculously vanilla and it is all just rather a bit craptastic. It's like EL James took over and though Sam Taylor Johnson was being a bit too good and showing her up. Pretty awful really. 
The fault for me lies with James's final say and Dornan's horrible acting. You wont go to hell for catching this on a plane. i heard thoughts saying that this would have been better if it was worse, but I think that if the director had been given free rein and Christian Grey had been better cast, this could have actually been quite a compelling film. What a fucking shame it really isn't.

Look, this isn't going to be a review that raves about how good this film is, because it truly is trash. I feel as though this film is a genius picture on many levels, due to its manipulative styles and ways of getting people into the theatre. Looking back on Fifty Shades of Grey, it really was just a marketing tactic for a certain demographic. Sure, fans of the book watched it and may have got some enjoyment out of it, but the story, accompanied by the god-awful dialogue, really does make this film a treat to watch, even if you can admit how bad it is. I have no idea how seriously the books are to be taken, nor do I ever intend on finding that out, but this film is an absolute blast to watch, because the dialogue is completely ridiculous. Here is why you should check out Fifty Shades of Grey, even though it's terrible.

Following Anastasia Steele and Christian Grey as they meet through a business meeting, she quickly becomes infatuated with him, only to realize that there is a lot more to him behind the scenes. Tormented by the fact that he likes to inflict pain onto women who enjoy it, he is very heavy into BDSM. Accepting her as his girlfriend and trying to get her to sign a non-disclosure agreement to participate in these events that would pleasure him, their relationship grows in very strange ways. Filled with horribly written dialogue and a plot that really doesn't go anywhere, this first instalment doesn't do to get fans to return, although I'm sure the readers will be there on day one of all three films.

While the story of this film is obviously not to be taken too seriously, the performances in both Dakota Johnson and Jamie Dornan definitely lifts the film from the ashes in my opinion. There chemistry may not be perfect, but they do give these roles their all, especially Johnson. These are some of the most irrelevant and dumb characters I have seen on-screen in quite some time, but their performances are what make them bearable. There are times when the dialogue coming out of their mouths is so terrible that I can do nothing but chuckle, but Anastasia could be completely in tears. There was clear effort in making this film better than it

The main reason people flocked out to see this film, was clearly due to the shock value. People who hadn't read the books were curious, people who knew it was going to be a poor film wanted a good laugh, and fans of the book were hoping to be satisfied. But were the scenes memorable in any way? Memorable in the sense that they are solely done for shock value, yes, but they really aren't that shocking, especially when they are limited even with an R rating. I did not go into this film hoping these scenes would be great though. I was hoping for great chemistry and compelling characters, which was a mistake from the very beginning. Having said all of this, these sequences should please fans of the book. In that way, I guess the film does its job.

In the end, Fifty Shades of Grey sets out to please the fans and draw in interested people. That is exactly what it accomplished and absolutely nothing more. With wooden characters and a plot that centres solely around the fact that a woman is unsure if she should be trusting this man, there really isn't much substance to be had. Overall, as I said, it does its core job for fans, but newcomers will either roll their eyes, find it funny, or walk out. Released on Valentine's Day, as are the sequels, it's the perfect spot for a film like this, especially if they are in the mood for some cash returns. Fifty Shades of Grey is a very, very bad film, but undeniably accomplished its goal. For that, I give it a few props.

Even at the height of its popularity (especially when the 1st edition came out), I just knew Hollywood would not keep their hands of this one, no matter how ridiculous the whole concept is. I guess this is where I should admit that I haven't read the book so this review won't be comparing the two or complaining about what the movie did or didn't do from the book. No, this review is just going to be based around the actual movie and for the life of me I can't see what all the hype is about. This E.L. James erotic best seller was actually conceived as a Twilight fan story, I cant even begin to imagine the level of atrocity that would have given birth to if the idea was picked up in the original over hyped mediocre Twilight series. Anyways lets gets to the plot, The story follows Anastasia Steele (Dakota Johnson), a depressingly ordinary college girl, who goes through life without many close friends outside her roommate leads an existence of convention and routine. This changes when her roommate asks her to interview Christian Grey (Jamie Dornan), an elusive, single billionaire who's consistent protection of his private life has warranted great question. From the moment she sees him, Anastasia is smitten with everything about him because he is everything she isn't: bold, confident, unafraid, and suave. One can tell just from the way Christian looks and speaks to Anastasia, having great patience and acceptance with her that he admires her for her own traits as well: she's simple, frightened, vulnerable, and just the kind of girl he's looking for. The two quietly hit it off, with Christian requesting simple things like coffee outings and simple hangouts before going through one of his many periods of being standoffish and confusing to Anastasia. Eventually, he reveals his motives; he's looking for a sexual relationship with no commitments and no conventionality in terms of going on dates. He wants sex and he wants it his way, proposing a contract to Anastasia in hopes she will become the submissive to his dominant, in which she'll stay at his spacious penthouse on weekends to engage in wild sexual escapades. Yup! this is the plot of an actual movie, not your usual porn production from Digital Playground or Naughty America, people actually invested in this movie! There are all sorts of major issues with the film, we can start with the laughable screenplay, which would have been rejected by the Lifetime channel and in fact, I'm going to guess that it would have been rejected has a five-year-old written it. The dialogue is without question some of the most laughable I've heard in a very long time. In fact, the movie seems to be lost in what decade it is because there are times that the "F" word is used and it's used in a way to where it's supposed to be shocking. Really? It's going to take more than that. The entire character development between the two lead characters is another joke and after a while you really can't buy into any of the melodrama and you've just got to sit back and laugh. Yet another problem is that the film just isn't erotic. Films like Fatal Attraction, Basic Instinct, 8mm are just a few examples that qualify as erotic films. A lot of the lack of erotic-ness has to be blamed on the director who just seems to have been the wrong fit for the material. Nothing from the erotic nature to the serious stuff works and everything is poorly edited. Dakota Johnson and Jamie Dornan fit their roles pretty well, they are good looking & awkward (I guess that's how they are supposed to be). However, the two completely lack any kind of chemistry together. Like I mentioned above the plot was originally meant to be Twiligth fan fiction, we cant help but notice the similarities between the lead protagonists (in comparison to the very boring Edward & Bella). Maybe that's intentional, again alluding to Grey's refusal to make this a relationship of any conventionality, but it's difficult to get wrapped up in the sex scenes when both parties seem disinterested in one another and bored. Furthermore, the acting of the two leads varies from acceptable to incredibly poor and contrived. On the whole 'Fifty Shades of Grey' may go down as one of the most poorly-written films of the film year in terms of having singular lines of dialog that are capable of producing unintentional laughs and sneers.  Combine the elements of bad dialog with unremarkable sex scenes and an an overall idiotic portrayal of a sex subculture, and you have a film that flat-lines where it should have stunned & entertained. Just as Mr Gray had said "This is fifty shades of f****d up"!

The plot is something a teenager could come up with, dull and predictable and the entire film hinges on a few erotic scenes that other films have done far better. 

No matter how they spin it the two main characters need serious therapy for their deep seeded erotic urges that the film tries to pass off as something wholesome.

The movie is fine. The BDSM is well treated and Dakota Johnson is the star of the whole film. Her acting is so lovable that the final scene is truly heartbreaking and that final part -"Christain", "Ana"- is a perfect finale.

The much-anticipated adaptation of the poorly written, literary atrocity is about as interesting as an R-rated Twilight film; just because you add some sex, your characters don't transcend their bland "romance" and TERRIBLE dialogue. Sam-Taylor Johnson did what she could with the material and scrapped the inner monologue (thank Christ) and I cannot deny that the film is shot well and that Dakota Johnson has presence and wit on-camera; the positives end there. This story is a complete fantasy and in no reality I can fathom would a woman tolerate an obsessive, stalker-type even if he was super rich and I feel it is degrading how quickly she became infatuated with him just because he has a fucking helicopter. I don't think I've ever seen more inconsistent characters before in my life with the constant flip-flop of being okay with the S&M, then wanting intimacy, then him saying he won't give it, then totally does, and by the end I did not give a crap about their "relationship". Jamie Dornan is merely okay as the lead, though he's sorely missing the intimidating quality about him required and you'll be rolling your eyes at some of the things he has to say. The selling point everyone's losing their shit over is obviously the sex scenes, which while pushing the boundaries of the R rating, don't amount to much and feel repetitive after the first night. Fifty Shades of Grey is an over-long gimmick-movie with no conflict, no realism, and zero credibility in the writing department and if you're into the whole taboo, S&M stuff, watch Secretary instead.

To be fair, the movie is a whole lot better than the book - not that this was a difficult task. At its best, it's the kind of movie you watch with a giddy grin. I liked "Movie-Ana" better than "Book-Ana". In contrast to the book, she comes off a little stronger and wittier in the movie... and she's definitely not so annoying, thanks to Kelly Marcel who didn't put any of that hideous monologue in her screenplay.
Sam Taylor-Johnson and Kelly Marcel tried hard with the direction and the screenplay, and the result was a movie that is far from being great, but not as embarrassing as that badly written book. Honestly, those two women did what they could, they saved what could be saved. The movie had some funny lines and thankfully it didn't take itself too seriously. Towards the ending tho, it became rather boring and I desperately wanted it to end. The ending, that was supposed to be dramatic and make viewers cry, barely made me feel... I felt sorry for the characters unrealistic behavior at the end, but since I never really connected with them I never really "felt".
It's certainly not the worst movie I've seen and like I said, the first half is actually pretty funny, but I still don't get the hype around it... I really don't.

Considering how lousy the book was written, and how cheesy the dialogue was, I think they actually did a pretty decent job at the movie. Ana was cute, and funny, and they didn't make her as lopsided as they did in the book (she's and english lit major with a 4.0 but has trouble working a computer). They glossed over Christian's magical "know everywhere she is" deal. It's there, but they don't address it much. They tried to inject a lot of humor into it. It's no masterpiece, obviously, however I'm going to give it a rating based on it's crappy origins and how far they were able to elevate it from that.

First of all I want to say I am a guy and I liked 50 Shades of Grey.  I also minored in psychology in college. I tend to find anything that deals with understanding the human condition fascinating. I wonder why I  chose trying to understand computers as a career path over people? This movie is categorised as a romance but it is a torrid sort. I actually liked 50 Shades of Grey but not for the reasons as how it's marketed but for the psychological depth of the two main characters. The movie is still running so I will refrain from going into too much detail. 

The movie is NOT about sex. Anyone who comes out of the theatre feeling they got their jollies off seeing some "soft porn" might be some sick motherf'rs. The movie is about 2 things: abuse of power in relationships and the effects of child abuse.  I felt uncomfortable thru the whole movie. Everything the male protagonist irked me. He displayed the same qualities of a psychopath. If he wasn't such a philanthropist and oh a billionaire of his own company and apparently the only eligible guy in the city, this movie would have more resembled a movie about a stalker on the prowl. 

But the story is much more than some messed up guy who expresses himself awkwardly through BDSM. It is about someone who tries to deal with his own inner issues as a result of suffering abuse in his own childhood through no fault of his own I should add. The female protagonist has a face as sweet as an angel but I suspect it will be revealed she has her own personal battles to deal with as well. I suspect hers might be on par with Christian Grey. Why else would she subject herself to the F'd up situation she can't get out of? Then again, we all find ourselves in situations we can't get out of. Maybe the real moral of the story should be to steer clear of domineering partners and find your equal. Now, I have not read the books nor plan to but I hear there are already sequels in the works to flesh out the rest of the issues these two are going to deal with. 

This movie is fascinating because it tackles real psychological issues. Child abuse has a way of manifesting in destructive ways in adulthood. I couldn't decide if actor Jamie Dornan was supposed to intentionally act stilted throughout the movie because of the trauma. I certainly did not see the attraction at all. He's more of a show off than a person of magnetic gravitas. Dakota Johnson sold me completely and her acting was believable. Look past the sex, the bondage, the skin on skin because these are really not the focus. 

The author hooked us with rope and have now forced us (you and me) to feel the pain of the main character(s). A woman emotionally trapped to a real F'd up guy and a guy who should've gotten therapy. Unfortunately, We are the submissive and they are our dominant. Why did the author choose BDSM to tell a romance?in the world of BDSM it is a negotiation of pain and pleasure appropriation between dominant and submissive. Whereas in a rape situation, there is no negotiation between victim and victimiser. No wonder I felt that uneasy feeling throughout the whole movie.

It is finally here, the movie every housewife saw opening weekend and every boyfriend was dragged to, and i feel sorry for what they had to sit through for two hours. For a book that was so highly praised by so many people this film was all kinds of terrible, from it's plot (or lack thereof) to its characters and dialogue this movie just failed to deliver in any way. Now i know i am not the target audience for this film but even if i am not the target audience i have to be able to have at least a half decent time watching it. Right from the very first Anastasia and Christian scene this move was just so cringeworthy and a complete borefest. This movie did a terrible job of creating and introducing these characters, one comes across as a weird, over-controlling freak (some words i cannot include here) and the other a very confused ,dumb and poorly written woman. Whoever wrote the dialogue for this film whether it was the same as the novel or updated for the film needs to retire their writing career because the conversations between the two leads are so boring, all the lines seem very fake, like this writer has never had a normal human conversation. Most of this crappy dialogue is the writer's fault for writing it but also Jamie Dornan was just completely bland in this role, his delivery of the lines were so robotic and fake that you didn't buy what they were saying for a second. I do believe that Anastasia did a half decent job while having to portray one of the dumbest characters who is completely incapable of making any kind of rational decision. Her scenes when she is away from Christian are more bearable, it is when they are together that it just gets unbearable to watch.

Now, the plot was just so plain and simple that for a whole 2 hours the movie went absolutely nowhere. The movie was not building up to any kind of event, it was just a series of conversations and sexual activities all spaced out over the two hours. Whoever read the script and thought that THIS would be able to capture the viewers attention the whole time was dead wrong. This film did its very best to make me fall asleep, but i fought it because i had to see what stupidity they would come up with next to keep the film going. This film was just filled with many, many weird and awkward conversations that just make you wonder why on earth this woman is interested in this man and why this man is so interested in this woman. With a bit of unsexy sex thrown in there a few times and one of the worst endings in film history this movie was a disaster waiting to happen. If it wasn't for Dakota Johnson actually making her character at times amusing this would have somehow been even lower. - 2.9/10

Love it or hate the idea, Fifty Shades of Grey is one of the biggest film releases this year. Strategically placed on a Valentines Day weekend release, the millions and millions of woman who were captivated by the highly successful novel series were lining up around the block to get their first taste of a live action Mr. Grey. 

Fifty Shades of Grey is basically Twilight's replacement. Funnily enough stemming from Twilight fan fiction, Fifty Shades follows an awkward young woman who is pursued by an improbable love interest, the main difference being that instead of Edward's vampirism, Mr. Grey sports a BDSM fetish, where he must dominate his sexual partner. And this was the big draw card to the novel, it's explicit sex scenes. But how would this translate to a modern major motion picture? Many people were shocked to find the film was rated MA rather than a hard R. Well I found that the sex scenes were quite tastefully shot, and the two leads bonded well together here, but I really thought it was going to go a whole lot further. The 'domination' scenes were pretty tame, I expected it to get pretty brutal, but I suppose we gotta leave some room for build up in the sequels. 

I thought the sexual tension between Anastasia and Mr. Grey was great for the most part. But then Jamie Dornan (Mr. Grey) would do something stupid like bite a piece of toast that Anastasia is holding or give a hollow line delivery that just broke any sense of coolness that this character had. In fact it is Dornan's performance that ultimately harms this film. He is almost good. But on the contrary,  Dakota Johnson, who plays Anastasia, is great as the girl next door type. A lot of people seem to have a problem with her but I felt that she played the role strongly and I believed her the whole way. 

I didn't love this film, it is lame, lovey dovey and cheesy, but that's what I expected. It is an interesting enough story that had me for most of the way, it does run a tad long though and I wasn't digging the ending much. But I'm sure it will be remedied in the inevitable sequel. If you have even the slightest interest in this film, you need to go see it in cinemas. 

3/5

By Ricky Miller

   'Fifty Shades of Grey'  -- much ado about nothing

"Fifty Shades of Grey" is an is an overblown melodrama that is on par with director Paul Verhoeven's "Showgirls" for degree of awfulness.  Dakota Johnson (TV's "Ben and Kate") is the naÃÃ,Â¯ve young girl who gets seduced into the world of masochist Christian Grey (Jamie Dornan, "Marie Antoinette").  

Going back to the  days of my youth, I actually read the books before 
I saw the movie. I did this with Stephen King's "Misery" and Tom Clancy's "The Hunt for Red October."  

Both were great movies, but the reason rested in the director's hands.  The reason both of the movies were so good rested in the resulting flicks done by Rob Reiner and John McTiernan.  Reiner steered Kathy Bates to an Oscar win for "Misery" while McTiernan introduced a star in the making with Alec Baldwin.
 
        Nowadays, I think the movie should stand alone, without having read the book.  
 
      With this in mind, I did not resort to reading the pages of E.L. James's  page turners.   Both screenwriters James (who also penned the novel it's based on)  and Kelly Marcel add nothing of any merit to the superficial and trite dialogue. 
         Another predicament with "Fifty Shades" is one does not care in the very least about these selfish lovebirds.  Sure, it might have been steamy and tantalizing on the page, but director Sam Taylor-Johnson never pulls one into the proceedings and their earth-quaking romance.
Dornan's selfish persona of Christian Grey is just that of a spoiled yahoo who does not really care for others, but just his own gluttonous selfish appetite.  Johnson's Anastasia Steele is seduced by Grey and all his shortcomings.
 
          Adding to the credibility of the movie is the appearance of Oscar-winner Marcia Gay Harden as Christian's psychologist mom, Dr. Grace Travelyan Grey.  Her appearance, although brief, shows how unimportant Christian is to the very scheme of things in real life.  Her persona is not one of ignorance, but of a person who is just prone to look the other way.

Looking back at so-called controversial movies of my youth like "9 1/2 Weeks," Zalman King's "Two Moon Junction" and "Wild Orchid," I think of how ludicrous it was to deem these movies controversial.  They are just bloody movies and nothing more.
Controversy aside, I just want to see a good movie. Paul Thomas Anderson's "Boogie Nights" was one of the better movies I have seen in the past 20 years.  The same goes for Michael Mann's cops-and-robbers tale "Heat," wherein an aged Robert DeNiro and Al Pacino square off in a pretzel-twisting suspense action-thriller. 
That is what I want in my movie.  Quality.  It's not asking for much, but that is what I want to spend my money on. 
"Fifty Shades of Grey" for all intents and purposes is a complete waste of time.  Johnson's  Anastasia is a woman who realizes all too late that there is more to life than the simple pleasure of appealing to one's loins.  Real life is far too important.
Grade:  C-

Big Al's Movie Review:
Fifty Shades of Grey

College student Anastasia Steele is introduced into the BDSM lifestyle after a chance meeting with Christian Grey, a billionaire businessman with a twisted past. 

This film was a laughable mistake. 

To be fair, the novel that it's based on is just guilty-pleasure fun, filled with the old good-girl-saves/changes-brooding-but-beautiful-billionaire-bad-boy fantasy. But what a reader's mind's eye will forgive from a subpar novel, a movie audience member's real eyes (and ears) will not. Sure, the script was weak, the miscasted actors couldn't act and the much anticipated sex scenes seemed tame but, I mean, at least the soundtrack was decent. 

Grade:  D-

Big Al says Fifty Shades of Grey is a renter...but only if you want to hate-watch.

As seen on Castle rock News by Deke The Movie Geek

Who's it for, fans of: cheesy romance novels, the Marquis De Sade, the Lifetime network, movies so bad they make you laugh out loud (at times unintended by the filmmakers to be funny, much to the horror of fellow moviegoers)

50 Shades of Grey is based upon an E.L. James novel that actually does hit upon some deep human issues - though unfortunately it does not have the ability to penetrate beneath some of the complexities it scratches upon. At the core of the film is the deep human desire to compensate for deep physical, emotional and mental trauma. The protagonists delve into the world of sadomasochism, because that represents to Mr. Grey, a device of controlling his environment and the response of others, especially the one he allows to be closest to him.

There is essentially a great deal of disappointment in a human attempting to micro-manage their world and those around him; a great fail in the area of relating to another. This leads to the conclusion that in our mutual yearning for fellowship and intimacy, that no amount of deviancy could ever satisfy or fulfill anyone. It's too bad this potentially great topic was put in the hands of filmmakers that chose to focus on sensationalism of sensuality.

It is funny that the film shot in an ironic 9  1/2 weeks, and it shows that the cast took only 5 days to learn their dialogue. The movie has also been banned in Kenya for moral reasons and, perhaps, should have been in the United States for artistic reasons. Ironically the Seahawks won their first Super Bowl during filming, but the choices made by the filmmakers amounted cinematically to not handing off to Marshawn Lynch in the last Superbowl: a bad call (to make this film) on their part. The film has enjoyed the commercial success of its shallow, fluffy book franchise it's based upon, thus we can sadly expect more of the same in future poorly made cinema lacking any REAL substance.
